resource.chars:
The author has proved that these tubules are physiologically 
true renal organs. The uric acid was extracted by 
boiling a large number of them in water, filtering,
and then evaporating the filtrate to dryness. The 
residue was treated with alcohol, filtered, and 
the residue so formed was dissolved in boiling 
water to which acetic acid was added. After 
standing for several hours, crystals of uric acid 
were deposited. These crystals were readily con-
verted into murexide.
When a fresh Malpighian tubule of <u>Pontia <\u> was placed 
upon a slide under the microscope, and crushed,
a drop of acetic acid added, and the whole covered 
by a cover-glass, rhombic and other crystalline 
forms were deposited. These crystals were also 
readily converted into murexide by the action of 
nitric acid and ammonia.
No other substance besides uric acid is present in the 
Malpighian tubules of <u>Pontia brassicae <\u>.*
[*] The Malpighian tubules of both the larva and imago were 
tested separately, but with the same result.
